mvt_properties.Description: Channel 21/22 brightness temperature of the fire pixel, measured in Kelvin.
mvt_properties.Title: Brightness Temperature (Channel 21/22)

mvt_properties.Description: Channel 31 brightness temperature of the fire pixel, measured in Kelvin.
mvt_properties.Title: Brightness Temperature 31 (Channel 31)

mvt_properties.Description: The algorithm produces 1km pixels at nadir, but pixels get bigger toward the edge of scan. This value reflects the actual along-scan pixel size.
mvt_properties.Title: Along-Scan Pixel Size

mvt_properties.Description: The algorithm produces 1km pixels at nadir, but pixels get bigger toward the edge of scan. This value reflects the actual along-track pixel size.
mvt_properties.Title: Along-Track Pixel Size

mvt_properties.Description: Indicates whether the fire point was observed during the ‘day’ or ‘night’.
mvt_properties.Title: Day/Night Flag

mvt_properties.Description: Satellite from which the fire is observed.
mvt_properties.Title: Satellite

mvt_properties.Description: The Fire Radiative Power (FRP) is a measure of the rate of radiant heat output from a fire. It has been demonstrated in small-scale experimental fires that the FRP of a fire is related to the rate at which fuel is being consumed (Wooster et al., 2005) and smoke emissions released (Freeborn et al., 2008).
mvt_properties.Title: Fire Radiative Power

mvt_properties.Description: This value is based on a collection of intermediate algorithm quantities used in the detection process. It is intended to help users gauge the quality of individual hotspot/fire pixels. Confidence estimates range between 0 and 100% and are assigned one of the three fire classes (low-confidence fire, nominal-confidence fire, or high-confidence fire).
mvt_properties.Title: Detection Confidence

mvt_properties.Description: The date of acquisition for this fire point. (YYYY-MM-DD)
mvt_properties.Title: Acquisition Date

mvt_properties.Description: The time of acquisition for this fire point, in UTC. (HHSS)
mvt_properties.Title: Acquisition Time

mvt_properties.Description: The collection (e.g. MODIS Collection 6) and source of data processing: Near Real-Time (NRT suffix added to collection) or Standard Processing (collection only).  Find out more on collections and on the differences between FIRMS data sourced from LANCE FIRMS and University of Maryland.
mvt_properties.Title: Collection and Source

mvt_properties.Description: Channel I-4 brightness temperature of the fire pixel, measured in Kelvin.
mvt_properties.Title: Brightness Temperature (Channel I-4)

mvt_properties.Description: Channel I-4 brightness temperature of the fire pixel, measured in Kelvin.
mvt_properties.Title: Brightness Temperature (Channel I-5)

mvt_properties.Description: The algorithm produces 375m pixels at nadir, but pixels get bigger toward the edge of scan. This value reflects the actual along-scan pixel size.
mvt_properties.Title: Along-Scan Pixel Size

mvt_properties.Description: The algorithm produces 375m pixels at nadir, but pixels get bigger toward the edge of scan. This value reflects the actual along-track pixel size.
mvt_properties.Title: Along-Track Pixel Size

mvt_properties.Description: Indicates whether the fire point was observed during the ‘day’ or ‘night’.
mvt_properties.Title: Day/Night Flag

mvt_properties.Description: Satellite from which the fire is observed.
mvt_properties.Title: Satellite

mvt_properties.Description: The Fire Radiative Power (FRP) is a measure of the rate of radiant heat output from a fire. It has been demonstrated in small-scale experimental fires that the FRP of a fire is related to the rate at which fuel is being consumed (Wooster et al., 2005) and smoke emissions released (Freeborn et al., 2008).
mvt_properties.Title: Fire Radiative Power

mvt_properties.Description: This value is based on a collection of intermediate algorithm quantities used in the detection process. It is intended to help users gauge the quality of individual hotspot/fire pixels. Confidence values are set to low, nominal and high.  Low confidence daytime fire pixels are typically associated with areas of sun glint and lower relative temperature anomaly (<15K) in the mid-infrared channel I4. Nominal confidence pixels are those free of potential sun glint contamination during the day and marked by strong (>15K) temperature anomaly in either day or nighttime data. High confidence fire pixels are associated with day or nighttime saturated pixels.  Please note: Low confidence nighttime pixels occur only over the geographic area extending from 11° E to 110° W and 7° N to 55° S. This area describes the region of influence of the South Atlantic Magnetic Anomaly which can cause spurious brightness temperatures in the mid-infrared channel I4 leading to potential false positive alarms. These have been removed from the NRT data distributed by FIRMS.
mvt_properties.Title: Detection Confidence

mvt_properties.Description: The date of acquisition for this fire point. (YYYY-MM-DD)
mvt_properties.Title: Acquisition Date

mvt_properties.Description: The time of acquisition for this fire point, in UTC. (HHSS)
mvt_properties.Title: Acquisition Time

mvt_properties.Description: The collection (e.g. VIIRS Collection 1) and source of data processing: Near Real-Time (NRT suffix added to collection) or Standard Processing (collection only).  Find out more on collections and on the differences between FIRMS data sourced from LANCE FIRMS and University of Maryland.
mvt_properties.Title: Collection and Source

pine_island_glacier_icebergb46_nov_2018.description: View the newest iceberg, B-46, from the Pine Island Glacier, Antarctica.
